author: Mahesh Langa
text:
Reshma Patel, who is on a hunger strike demanding the release of Hardik Patel in Ahmedabad on Saturday.- Photo: Vijay Soneji

In a bid to placate Patidars who have revived their agitation against the Gujarat government, Chief Minister Anandiben Patel has asked the State Home Department to withdraw 74 police cases involving 380 Patels who were booked for rioting.

However, the government’s latest decision does not include serious cases of sedition in which the agitation leader Hardik Patel and his top aides are involved.

According to State government spokesman and Health Minister Nitin Patel, Ms. Patel held several meetings with the Patel community leaders and decided to withdraw “lighter cases.”

“No relief to Hardik Patel and 13 others who are in jail facing serious charges and their bail pleas have also been repeatedly rejected by various courts,” Mr. Nitin Patel said.

“Other cases will also be reviewed in the next phase to look into the possibility of withdrawal,” the spokesperson said.

Interestingly, the government’s move is also seen as a pre-emptive measure ahead of a rally the opposition Congress planned to hold to press for the release of the Patidars languishing in jails.

“The opposition party is politicising the issue by spreading misinformation that thousands of Patidars are in jails,” Mr. Nitin Patel said, adding “as per the police records, 1,750 people were arrested after the agitation in August-September and only 14 are in jail while others have been released on bail.”
title: Gujarat decides to withdraw cases against Patidars
